author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

How is it related to bioinformatics? From a cursory look, I don't see any bio-specific function in the package.

Some functions already exist in Base, some in dedicated packages with a cleaner interface, some are trivial, and none seem documented at all.

[noblock]
It is related because it is already being used in a few public software, one of them being popular: `GSEA.jl`, `Immunogram.jl`, `TCRGram.jl`, `BioGPS.jl`, and a few other packages.
Your suggestions about commenting are noted already and queued to be done later. Thank you.
[noblock] You say that it has been used in various public software, but I can only find `GSEA.jl`. Could you provide some links to the rest?

[noblock] Hi @SyxP, thanks for looking into this. Links for `.jl` repositories other than mine are not available because they are private not mine. These are their most public status. `BioGPS.jl` is the newer version of https://github.com/UCSD-CCAL/onco_gps_paper_analysis . `Immunogram.jl` and `TCRGram.jl` are current projects at our lab and co-developed by Azam M at Mark Davis Lab at Stanford. https://github.com/immunogram is the organization these will migrate to. `GSEA.jl` is ready and will be transferred to https://github.com/GSEA-MSigDB. We just submitted a grant, which requires this to be done as well. Finally, https://github.com/guardiome 's new backend relies on this package as well. This is why I wanted to register this package so that I can get to them one by one.

I see the concern that perhaps BioinformaticsCore.jl is a general name, but GSEACore.jl may be too specific. I feel that given the other packages that are going to come after this one, perhaps BioinformaticsCore.jl is ok to register.

My original point was basically the opposite: the name BioinformaticsCore suggests that this package contains fundamental bio-related functions, but most/all of them actually seem arbitrary utility functions.
I could pick basically any source file as an example to illustrate this, but here are a few specifics: 
https://github.com/KwatMDPhD/BioinformaticsCore.jl/blob/main/src/Array/error_duplicate.jl
https://github.com/KwatMDPhD/BioinformaticsCore.jl/blob/main/src/FeatureXSample/target.jl
https://github.com/KwatMDPhD/BioinformaticsCore.jl/blob/main/src/Vector/sort_like.jl
https://github.com/KwatMDPhD/BioinformaticsCore.jl/blob/main/src/Table/read.jl

Maybe, a better name is something like UCSDUtilities?

_disclaimer: I'm not a `General` maintainer_

Thanks for the comment. I see your points. I agree with you. And I have made issues based on your comments. Thank you.

But I think this package is valid to register.

First, by choice, we tried to have as many small functions, making it easy to split it as needed later. The API-level functions are not in the "Core" package by design.

Next, no package is perfect, especially in the early days. Often packages evolve, compartmentalize, and mature. I believe this is the case for `BioinformaticsCore.jl`. The bioinformatics ecosystem needs work in Julia. And it does not come near perfect overnight. The good ecosystems develop - as needed - one part at a time. Often, they start as a person's personal repository and then get community feedback, branching into more packages and even into an organization. I wish for such a trajectory for this package. Yet now, the most important thing is that we keep going forward and make things people want to use.

I believe that this package should have the right to develop into an echo system slowly, as needed. Over time, this should contain lower-level functions, reusing others' stable ones as much, while enabling higher-level bioinformatics functions.

"Premature optimization is the beginning of all evil" is a famous quote in computer science. A perfectly organized package that no one uses does not grow. But a package that is used more and scrutinized more can develop into one with a elegant structure. I hope you could give our community a chance.

@KwatMDPhD In browsing the package, the code appears to be utilities being prepared in support of bioinformatics capabilities - and perhaps a name that suggests that is better. Later as the package grows, it should be possible to refactor it and have a BioinformaticsCore.jl.

Also, the other reason to avoid calling this Core is that it has a large footprint in terms of package dependencies. The Project.toml will pull in a lot of dependencies, and you probably want a tighter core package with core computational capabilities.

The other thing is that when coming up with an opinionated set of packages for a domain, people often use a name for the whole project - like Flux.jl, Turing.jl, JuMP.jl, SciML, etc. Then as interfaces standardize, a core package is often refactored out to allow multiple implementations of the abstract APIs.

Is it possible to come up with a different name for this ecosystem of packages you mentioned? I think it may serve the purpose better. Apologies, that this may need some refactoring and renaming.
Thank you for the messages. Feel free to close this. I will respond to the feedback and retry. Thank you @aplavin and @ViralBShah üôè

body:
- Registering package: BioinformaticsCore
- Repository: https://github.com/KwatMDPhD/BioinformaticsCore.jl
- Created by: @KwatMDPhD
- Version: v0.11.22
- Commit: b27546a5a769fa4d0bdfed5504e52116337820f5
- Git reference: HEAD
- Description: Core functions for bioinformatics packages and projects such as gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA.jl) üß∞
title: New package: BioinformaticsCore v0.11.22
